3085.text: to looking back and saying like,

3088.text: like perfect again in this moment in time.

3096.text: Can you talk a little bit about the transition that your company

3100.text: made between filling a simple need as a small company selling

3105.text: to consumers and you know that they want a product and then

3106.text: being able to actually empower those consumers,

3110.text: like fulfil yourself and like being able to empower

3112.text: your consumers and what contributes to that cycle.

3119.text: So the question is about how - what was the transition for ModCloth

3126.text: from going from like a purely transactional relationship with our

3129.text: community to actually empowering them to be part of the process.

3135.text: Yeah, I think - I mean I do think a lot of that

3140.text: for ModCloth story was timing for us.

3144.text: Like I said, we were kind of - I was like thinking about taking the business

3151.text: to the next level at this time where Facebook was really gaining traction

3157.text: and like all this stuff on the social web was happening.

3160.text: So for me, it like intuitively made sense that whatever business

3165.text: I was starting like this had to be a part of it like I look at

3168.text: the way I was using Facebook and the way my friends were interacting

3172.text: on Facebook and it made sense to me that like because my customers

3176.text: were probably pretty similar to me and my friends that they would

3179.text: want to interact in that way as well and not just with the brand

3183.text: but with kind of each other on the website.

3186.text: And giving them that opportunity was going to be something

3190.text: that would be not just useful for us because we learn more

3194.text: about them that it would actually be a brand differentiator.

3198.text: And I think the transition really was around the

3203.text: time that we launched our Be the Buyer program

3208.text: like having that kind of brainstorm of like,

3212.text: yeah, we could - let's ask our customers and let's get them involved,

3218.text: It really was just like confluence of what we were thinking about,

3225.text: what we were excited about and what was happening in the market like -

3230.text: and in the broader like social world that allow that to happen.

3234.text: Was that too vague or does that answer your question?

3240.text: I like to know you currently have your own designers and

3244.text: also I would like to know are you buying and selling globally

3247.text: and what's been your experience with that?

3251.text: So the question was if we have our own designers which we do,

3254.text: so it's definitely something that we see as a big part of ModCloth's

3260.text: future and moving forward is doing more and more proprietary design.

3266.text: We release about 150 designs a quarter right now,

3271.text: they are coming from our own internal design

3272.text: team and we see that scaling quickly.

3277.text: The other part of the question was whether we work with international

3281.text: designers globally and kind of what that...

3286.text: So we do sell around the world.

3288.text: Our audience is mostly here in the U.S.

3291.text: but we do have like a fairly substantial following in Canada

3294.text: and Australia and like some of the other English speaking countries

3297.text: you'd expect and like high English speaking countries.

3300.text: We do work with designers based around the world and

3304.text: it can be - it's incredible from a branding perspective

3308.text: being able to introduce a designer to the U.S.

3310.text: for the first time and bring them into a new market,

3313.text: it's great for their business too and for us like

3316.text: it's part of how we become known as a place to - you

3319.text: can find stuff that you can't get anywhere else.

3322.text: But from a purely like retail business perspective,

3326.text: it can definitely be a challenge.

3327.text: It's hard for designers that haven't

3331.text: worked with companies in the U.S.

3333.text: before just like all the actual logistics of like bringing

3336.text: product in and making sure it's like going to get through

3339.text: customs and going to be able to sell in the U.S.

3342.text: It can be - because we work with, we really value independent designs,

3348.text: we work with a lot of independent designers and some of

3350.text: them are really great at design and not so good at logistics

3355.text: and some of the other parts of their business.

3356.text: So we have to kind of step in and fill that role.

3368.text: it's really a cutthroat and it's really a competitive

3371.text: space and I know a lot of brands they go over now,

3374.text: you see the craziest campaigns but I am just curious what was the

3378.text: one thing ModCloth did differently that got its early adopters?

3383.text: So the question was what did ModCloth

3385.text: do differently to get early adopters.

3388.text: And I think - when I think back to the real early adopters

3392.text: like people that were joining the brand in 2006 and 2007,

3396.text: what we did differently was really go where our customers were at

3399.text: a time when other fashion brands weren't thinking about those spaces.

3404.text: So being like one of the first brands to really build the fan

3408.text: page on Facebook for this audience going to up and coming like

3415.text: celebrity gossip bloggers and personal style bloggers because

3418.text: we knew - we even like we used to do a lot of advertising,

3422.text: we still do, but like we do a lot of

3425.text: So like blogs that post pictures of like bunnies and kitties

3428.text: and that sort of thing which isn't fashion related,

3431.text: so it wasn't like entirely clear to the broader industry

3433.text: that they should go and find customers there.

3436.text: But we - like I knew because that's the stuff that I

3441.text: was interested in and it was new and it was up and

3443.text: coming and like my friends were interested in it.

3446.text: So we were able to go and like find our customer where she was at and

3450.text: I think that was definitely what really spoke to our early adopters.

3455.text: They looked at us and saw us as,

3458.text: in some ways, like we are early adopters as well like we

3461.text: were the first to work with - have partnerships with certain

3466.text: fashion bloggers and like be working with them to create

3469.text: great content that didn't feel like an ad but talked about

3473.text: the brand and like got brand awareness out there.

3477.text: Susan, thank you so much it's been fantastic.
